headline.main: A New Story For 2 Rivals From the 70's

lead_paragraph: Bob Woodward arrived in the newsroom of The Washington Post around noon on Sept. 11, walked up to the executive editor, Leonard Downie Jr., and said ''What do you want me to do?'' Across town, Seymour M. Hersh was on the phone, working intelligence sources he had cultivated for three decades. Even before the trade center towers had collapsed, the editor of The New Yorker, David Remnick, had called to say: You are working on this for the next year. In the two months since, some of the most startling and controversial information to emerge from the crisis has appeared under their bylines, like the text of the operation manual and spiritual guide left behind by the hijackers (Mr. Woodward) or the National Security Agency's intercepts of conversations of the Saudi royal family, revealing their internal squabbles (Mr. Hersh).
abstract: Article on Bob Woodward of Washington Post and Seymour M Hersh, now with New Yorker, competing while reporting on America's battle against terrorism; both had previously competed in 1970's while reporting on Watergate scandal; photo (M)
